description: From Middle English meten, from Old English metan (“to measure, mete out, mark off, compare, estimate; pass over, traverse”), from Proto-West Germanic *metan, from Proto-Germanic *metaną (“to measure”), from Proto-Indo-European *med- (“to measure, consider”).

Cognate with Scots mete (“to measure”), Saterland Frisian meete (“to measure”), West Frisian mjitte (“to measure”), Dutch meten (“to measure”), German messen (“to measure”), Swedish mäta (“to measure”), Latin modus (“limit, measure, target”), Ancient Greek μεδίμνος (medímnos, “measure, bushel”), Ancient Greek μέδεσθαι (médesthai, “care for”), Old Armenian միտ (mit, “mind”).

verbs.description: mete (third-person singular simple present metes, present participle meting, simple past and past participle meted)

examples: Measured not out thy little span
For thee to take the meting-rod

entries.meaning: (transitive, usually with “out”) To dispense, measure (out), allot (especially punishment, reward etc.).
examples: Match'd with an agèd wife, I mete and dole
Unequal laws unto a savage race

description: From Middle English mete, borrowed from Old French mete (“boundary, boundary marker”), from Latin mēta (“post, goal, marker”). Cognate with the second element in Old English wullmod (“distaff”).

entries.meaning: A boundary or other limit; a boundary-marker; mere.

adjectives.description: mete (comparative more mete, superlative most mete)
